image.altText: Cars stalled in morning peak hour traffic in Annerley, Brisbane

items.synopsis: The ASX falls after the release of the September quarter inflation data, with fuel, electricity and rents behind the higher-than-expected jump, as investors weigh the possibility of a November rate hike by the RBA. Follow live.

title.children: Rising fuel prices behind higher-than-expected jump in inflation, ASX falls as markets consider possible rate hike

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: You'd be forgiven if you thought this blog was just the inflation show today (it's an important piece of economic data, after all!), but there's a related piece of business news I haven't touched on — Woolworths released its first quarter sales results for the 2024 financial year. In the 14 weeks from July 1 to October 1 this year, Woolworths has seen a 5.3% increase in its total group sales compared to the same time last year. In dollar values, that comes in at $17.2 billion. It's slightly less than what analysts had predicted (they thought there'd be a 5.5% increase) but CEO Brad Banducci says it's a "solid" result in light of inflation moderating. He says deflation for fruits, vegetables and meats has led to lower input costs, which have led to "lower retail prices" in its food businesses (that is, its supermarkets). "Looking ahead, we have strong plans in place for the key Christmas and holiday trading period," he said. "While sales trends in October have remained broadly in line with the trend lines in Q1, the trading environment remains uncertain and value for money remains a key focus for our customers across all our businesses. "Keeping our team safe and helping all our customers have an inspirational and affordable festive season remains our top priority ." The release of Woolworths' first quarter results comes ahead of their AGM tomorrow morning.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Woolworths sales total $17.2b since July as food inflation costs affects prices

Woolworths
released its first quarter sales results for the 2024 financial year.
In the 14 weeks from July 1 to October 1 this year, Woolworths has seen a
5.3% increase in its total group sales
compared to the same time last year. In dollar values, that comes in at
$17.2 billion
It's slightly less than what analysts had predicted (they thought there'd be a 5.5% increase) but
CEO Brad Banducci
says it's a "solid" result in light of inflation moderating.
He says deflation for
fruits, vegetables and meats
has led to lower input costs, which have led to
"lower retail prices"
in its food businesses (that is, its supermarkets).
"Looking ahead, we have strong plans in place for the key Christmas and holiday trading period," he said.

"While sales trends in October have remained broadly in line with the trend lines in Q1, the trading environment remains uncertain and value for money remains a key focus for our customers across all our businesses.
"Keeping our team safe and
helping all our customers have an inspirational and affordable festive season remains our top priority
The release of Woolworths' first quarter results comes ahead of their AGM tomorrow morning.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says the federal government is not considering a temporary cut to the fuel excise, despite inflation data showing fuel prices saw their highest quarterly rise since March 2022. The federal government charges 49 cents a litre on petrol purchased at the bowser, as part of a fuel excise. The previous Coalition government temporarily halved the tax in March last year for six months, after Russia's invasion of Ukraine caused a massive global spike in oil prices. The current government opted not to extend the excise cut when it expired last September, with government estimates suggesting the temporary cut resulted in about $5.6 billion of lost tax revenue during those six months. But when asked today if the government was looking at reducing the excise to ease cost-of-living pressures, Mr Chalmers said it's currently not on the table. "Obviously in future budgets we will contemplate what measures are necessary in our economy consistent with our strict approach to fiscal discipline," he replied. "But it's not something we have been working on now."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Don't expect another cut to the fuel excise despite rising petrol prices

children.content: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says the federal government is
not considering a temporary cut to the fuel excise
, despite inflation data showing fuel prices saw their highest quarterly rise since March 2022.
The federal government charges 49 cents a litre on petrol purchased at the bowser, as part of a fuel excise.
The previous Coalition government
temporarily halved the tax in March last year
for six months, after Russia's invasion of Ukraine caused a
massive global spike in oil prices
The current government opted not to extend the excise cut when it expired last September, with government estimates suggesting the temporary cut resulted in
about $5.6 billion of lost tax revenue
during those six months.
But when asked today if the government was looking at reducing the excise to ease cost-of-living pressures, Mr Chalmers said it's currently not on the table.
"Obviously in future budgets we will contemplate what measures are necessary in our economy consistent with our strict approach to fiscal discipline," he replied.
"But
it's not something we have been working on
now."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There's a few questions coming in asking if fuel is the only reason for the acceleration in the consumer price index (or inflation) over the three months to September. Fuel was by far the biggest factor, but there's plenty more contributing to the increase — so let's break them down. What were the most significant contributors? Fuel prices, up 7.2% (The highest quarterly rise since March 2022) Electricity, up 4.2% Insurance, up 2.3% Rents, up 2.2% (Annual rental prices rose 7.6%, the largest increase since 2009) New house purchases, up 1.3% What was behind their increases? Fuel: Higher global oil prices Electricity: Higher wholesale prices being passed onto customers since July, partially offset by Energy Bill Relief rebates from July Insurance: Higher premiums for house, house contents and motor vehicle insurance Rents: Low vacancy rates, but moderated by increases in Commonwealth Rent Assistance New house purchases: Builders passing on labour and material costs Were there any falls? Yes — there were offsets during the September quarter for child care, fruit and vegetables, and domestic holiday travel and accommodation Child care fell 13.2%, after changes to the Child Care Subsidy increased the amount received by more than a million families in July Fruit and vegetables saw price falls of 3.7% because of favourable growing conditions Domestic holiday travel and accommodation fell 2.5% as there were no school holidays in August, reducing demand for airfares and accommodation It's also worth pointing out that the ABS says those significant contributors to inflation could have seen even higher increases had there not been support measures in place. The ABS's head of price statistics, Michelle Marquardt, says the rent assistance reduced the overall rent increases by 0.3%, while electricity prices would have increased 18.6% in the September quarter without the Energy Bill Relief rebates. Similarly, childcare prices would have increased 6.7% without the Child Care Subsidy reducing out-of-pocket costs for households.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What contributed to inflation accelerating in the September quarter?

children.content: There's a few questions coming in asking if fuel is the only reason for the acceleration in the consumer price index (or inflation) over the three months to September.
Fuel was by far the biggest factor, but there's plenty more contributing to the increase — so let's break them down.
What were the most significant contributors?
Fuel prices, up 7.2% (The highest quarterly rise since March 2022)
Electricity, up 4.2%
Insurance, up 2.3%
Rents, up 2.2% (Annual rental prices rose 7.6%, the largest increase since 2009)
New house purchases, up 1.3%
What was behind their increases?
Fuel: Higher global oil prices
Electricity: Higher wholesale prices being passed onto customers since July, partially offset by Energy Bill Relief rebates from July
Insurance: Higher premiums for house, house contents and motor vehicle insurance
Rents: Low vacancy rates, but moderated by increases in Commonwealth Rent Assistance
New house purchases: Builders passing on labour and material costs
Were there any falls?
Yes — there were offsets during the September quarter for child care, fruit and vegetables, and domestic holiday travel and accommodation
Child care fell 13.2%, after changes to the Child Care Subsidy increased the amount received by more than a million families in July
Fruit and vegetables saw price falls of 3.7% because of favourable growing conditions
Domestic holiday travel and accommodation fell 2.5% as there were no school holidays in August, reducing demand for airfares and accommodation
It's also worth pointing out that the ABS says those significant contributors to inflation
could have seen even higher increases
had there not been support measures in place.
The ABS's head of price statistics, Michelle Marquardt, says the
rent assistance reduced the overall rent increases by 0.3%
, while
electricity prices would have increased 18.6%
in the September quarter without the Energy Bill Relief rebates.
Similarly,
childcare prices would have increased 6.7%
without the Child Care Subsidy reducing out-of-pocket costs for households.
